Every single morning, every single day, every day you trade, you need to go through this

it's this very objectivity that will protect you. It will help you, you know, understand

So let's begin. Firstly, you need to ask yourself the question, when you look at
Now, the very simple premise is that when the market is being driven fundamentally,
there is a lot of flow in the market.
Technicals are far less important, so volume profiling will become far less effective.
However, when the markets are technical, it's going to be far better to employ technical
type strategies.
So that's the first question you ask yourself.
Secondly, is there conviction in the move?
By conviction we mean, is there confidence, is there momentum, is there high volume, is
there belief in this move, does the market really believe that prices should either
be higher or lower?
Then, is there a flight to safety?
In other words, when the market is moving risk on or risk off, we get flows that
are being allocated across various asset classes.
So it's important to understand, is there a genuine move in the market that is occurring
because of panic, because of fear, because of maybe political risk, or is it just normal
market moves that are occurring?
Then are there any strong correlations?
At times, if you look over the past couple of months, with all the US Federal Reserve

dollar.
So whilst this strong correlation exists, we need to ensure that we're not going against

You know, when the correlations are in play, we don't want to be using strategies
Now again, correlations become stronger and weaker over time, so it's important to understand
when there are correlations across various asset classes.
The next thing, what is the market condition?
Is it trending?
Are we in an early, late or mature phase of trending?
Or are we bracketing, moving sideways?
What is the inventory of the market?
In other words, what is the net position of the market?
Are there quite a few longs in the market?
What kind of longs in the market? Are they longer term, medium term, day traders, or are they short term?
Then, bracketing. How's the market moving? Are we at the top of the bracket, or are we at the bottom of the bracket?
How are we moving between the bracket? Where's the most volatility coming within the bracket?
Now, the reason we assess the market conditions is so that we can ensure we're employing our strategies in the right context or conditions of the market.
What is the volume doing at that point? Is it higher or is it lower? Is it moving higher
